instruction: [INST] Analyze this file to learn MacBook motherboard repair. The 'definitions' section explains key technical terms. The 'threads' section contains real-world repair discussions. Use both sections to understand and learn how to troubleshoot MacBook issues. Posts from username 'larossmann' , 'dukefawks' , and '2informaticos' are posts from trusted experts.[/INST]

definitions.820-3209: What is 820-3209? a LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER.
definitions.U7000: What is U7000? U7000 refers to the ISL6258 or ISL6259 charging IC on Macbooks from 2008-2012.
definitions.SMBUS_BATT_SCL: What is SMBUS_BATT_SCL? SMBUS_BATT_SCL is the clock line of an I2C data line between the battery charging chip that creates PPBUS_G3H, the system management controller(SMC), the battery, and the battery indicator LED..
definitions.SMBUS_BATT_SDA: What is SMBUS_BATT_SDA? SMBUS_BATT_SDA is the data line of an I2C data line between the battery charging chip that creates PPBUS_G3H, the system management controller(SMC), the battery, and the battery indicator LED..
definitions.R5281: What is R5281? Pullup resistor between PP3V42_G3H and SMBUS_SMC_5_G3_SCL which is a data line that allows the SMC to communicate with the battery and the battery charging chip. This line is necessary for the battery to be recognized. With red probe on ground, diode mode should measure 0.441 on pin 2 of this resistor. .
definitions.ISL6259: What is ISL6259? This is a charging chip for Macbook motherboards from 2010 through 2015.

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3209</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>: Not seeing battery
threads.message:
Anyone have any suggestion. Have a MacBook Air 13 <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3209</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> that's not seeing the battery. I've tried a known good battery from another unit with the same result.

Only issue i'm seeing so far is the <SIGNAL>SMBUS_BATT_SCL</SIGNAL> which reads about 2.84v (3.4v on a good logic board) while <SIGNAL>SMBUS_BATT_SDA</SIGNAL> reads about 3.4v.

Ive replace <CHIP>U7000</CHIP> and checked <RESISTOR>R5281</RESISTOR> (which reads 3.4v on pin 1 and 2.84 on pin 2). The only thing i haven't done is pulled the smc. Just wanted to make sure there wasn't anything else i need to check or could be the issue. 

And yes, there was corrosion on the board, which i ran through ultrasonic clean (took images of all corrosion before cleaning).

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3209</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>: Not seeing battery
threads.message:
Compare resistance to ground (diode mode) on SCL/SDA lines.
I bet you have lower value on SCL:
There is not allowed more than 1% difference; usually less than 0.5%.
<DIODE>D6950</DIODE> is not stuffed, so <CHIP>ISL6259</CHIP> and SMC suspect.
But clean first battery connector J6950.
You may need to remove it, or even replace.
Leave SMC as last option...

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3209</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>: Not seeing battery
threads.message:
Both SCL/SDA have resistance measurement of 0.46Mohms and diode measurement of 0.569(SCL)/0.565(SDA).
Will be pulling the battery connector soon. Would you happen to know where i could find these particular type of connector. I had search in the past but could never find them.

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3209</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>: Not seeing battery
threads.message: Pull from a donor board. Use heat from the bottom to remove it 450 celsius 120 airflow the other side of the board under the connector to get it to come off without melting the plastic.

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3209</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>: Not seeing battery
threads.message:
So it looks like the issue may be due to the corrosion cause I noticed when I press on the board slightly, SCL is back to 3.4v. 
Looks like the corrosion runs deep between the layers.

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3209</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>: Not seeing battery
<LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3209</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>: Not seeing battery
threads.message: Rebelled the SMC. This time SCL is back to reading consistent 2.84v and not swinging from 2.84 to 3.4 anymore.

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3209</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>: Not seeing battery
